Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: I was just about to step out the door with my trash bag when I noticed the bins by the curb—only half-full, plenty of space left. As a neighbor, I always try to be considerate, never overfilling or leaving a mess for others. But today, I hesitated, wondering if I should wait until next week to avoid hogging the space. Just then, my phone buzzed—a reminder that my first client was due in five minutes. I rushed to the salon, still thinking about the bins. As I set up my station, a nervous woman entered, glancing around uncertainly. As a hairdresser, I’m expected to greet clients warmly, put them at ease, and make them feel welcome. But my mind kept drifting back to the trash bins and whether my neighbors would be annoyed if I filled them up. I forced a smile, trying to focus on the client, but the tug-of-war between being a good neighbor and a good hairdresser gnawed at me, leaving me torn between two worlds, unsure which expectation to meet first.
